questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia


Lewy body dementia is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B12 deficiency: Reversible with supplementation.
 

Option B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus: Reversible with shunting.
 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Reversible with thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.3, indicating acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The elevated pCO2 of 60 mmHg (normal: 35-45 mmHg) points to a respiratory cause of the acidosis, specifically respiratory acidosis. In COPD patients, chronic CO2 retention is common, leading to increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels as a compensatory mechanism. However, in acute respiratory acidosis, the metabolic compensation is typically inadequate, as seen by the HCO3- level of 28 mEq/L (normal: 22-28 mEq/L). The inadequate compensation suggests an acute exacerbation rather than a chronic condition, as chronic respiratory acidosis would have a more elevated bicarbonate level (>30 mEq/L).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, not acidosis. The patient's presentation does not fit this scenario.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation: Hypoventilation causes respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis. This choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation: Adequate metabolic compensation would show higher bicarbonate levels (>30 mEq/L). The patient's bicarbonate level indicates inadequate compensation, ruling out this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute respiratory acidosis due to COPD exacerbation, expect hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation, indicated by elevated pCO2 and only slightly elevated HCO3- levels.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

 

History is suggestive of chronic diarrhea with malabsorption occurring at the proximal small intestine (duodenum+ jejunum) causing protein loss (ascites, weight loss diarrhea), Osteoporosis (calcium, magnesium), and Iron deficiency (anemia).

 

All above in a young patient should hint towards the possibility of celiac disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TSH levels: While important for evaluating thyroid function, symptoms of hypothyroidism can overlap with some celiac disease symptoms (like fatigue), but the gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies strongly point towards a primary gastrointestinal cause.

 

Option B. C-peptide levels: C-peptide tests are used to evaluate insulin production levels and are more relevant in the context of diabetes management, not indicated here.

 

Option C. Urine sugar and ketone: This test is used to diagnose and manage diabetes by detecting sugar and ketones in urine, not related to the suspected diagnosis of celiac disease based on the provided symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient presenting with symptoms consistent with malabsorption, including gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies like iron and calcium, testing for celiac disease with an IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test should be considered as a critical diagnostic step. This helps in confirming the diagnosis and facilitating appropriate dietary and medical management.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Celiac disease/Chapter 325

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

 

Systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma, is characterized by fibrosis and tightening of the skin, particularly on the face and extremities. The presence of numbness in the fingertips is often due to Raynaud's phenomenon, which is common in systemic sclerosis and results from vasospasm and ischemia.

 

The positive ANA test with a nucleolar pattern is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis. This pattern is seen in more than 95% of patients with scleroderma. Specific antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis include anti-centromere antibodies (often found in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis) and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies (associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with positive ANA, but the nucleolar pattern is not typically associated with Sjogren's. The physical findings of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms and often includes positive ANA. However, the nucleolar pattern is less common in SLE. The characteristic features of SLE include malar rash, arthritis, and serositis, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis. While ANA can be positive in rheumatoid arthritis, the nucleolar pattern and symptoms of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

choices.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L
pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg
pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed to have CFTR gene mutations. What is the defective channel? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cl

 

Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) gene mutations lead to defective chloride channels. The CFTR protein regulates the transport of chloride ions across epithelial cell membranes. In cystic fibrosis, mutations in the CFTR gene result in dysfunctional chloride channels, leading to the production of thick, sticky mucus. This thick mucus can cause various problems, including chronic respiratory infections, pancreatic enzyme insufficiency, and other complications.

 

The defective chloride channels are the underlying cause of the clinical manifestations seen in cystic fibrosis, as they disrupt the normal movement of chloride and sodium ions in and out of cells, thereby affecting the hydration and viscosity of secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na:  Sodium channels are not primarily affected by CFTR mutations. Although sodium transport can be indirectly affected due to the dysfunction in chloride transport, sodium channels themselves are not defective in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. K: Potassium channels are not involved in the pathophysiology of cystic fibrosis. The disease specifically involves chloride transport.

 

Option D. Ca:  Calcium channels are not affected by CFTR gene mutations. The defective channel in cystic fibrosis is specific to chloride ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the CFTR gene lead to defective chloride channels, which are responsible for the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of central cyanosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothermia

 

Central cyanosis occurs when there is a significant amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood, typically due to issues with oxygenation or hemoglobin abnormalities.

 

In contrast, hypothermia leads to peripheral cyanosis, not central cyanosis. In hypothermia, the blood flow is sluggish due to vasoconstriction, particularly in the extremities, which results in a bluish discoloration of the skin. However, the central organs typically remain oxygenated.

 

Other Options:

 

Central cyanosis can be caused by several factors:

 

Option A. Methemoglobinemia: This condition involves the presence of methemoglobin in the blood, which does not carry oxygen effectively, leading to central cyanosis.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula: This abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lungs allows blood to bypass the alveoli, leading to poorly oxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation, causing central cyanosis.

 

Option C. High Altitude: At high altitudes, the reduced atmospheric pressure leads to lower oxygen availability, causing hypoxemia and central cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia causes only peripheral cyanosis due to sluggish blood flow, not central cyanosis

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5
Increased risk of formation of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1 Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with Hyperkalemia

 

Type 1 RTA (distal RTA) is characterized by hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. The classic distal RTA presents with hypokalemia, a non-AG metabolic acidosis, low urinary NH4+ excretion (positive UAG, low urine [NH4+]), and inappropriately high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Hyperkalemia is instead a characteristic feature of Type 4 RTA, which involves generalized distal nephron dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Associated with nephrolithiasis: Type 1 RTA patients typically have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, which lead to nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease. The reduced urinary citrate and increased calcium excretion create an environment favorable for stone formation.

 

Option B. Failure to acidify urine to a pH of < 5:  A hallmark of Type 1 RTA is the inability to acidify urine below pH 5.5 despite systemic acidosis. This occurs due to a defect in H+ secretion in the distal tubule, leading to persistently elevated urine pH even when blood pH is low.

 

Option C. Increased risk of formation of urinary stones:  The combination of hypocitraturia (reduced urinary citrate, which normally inhibits stone formation) and hypercalciuria (increased calcium excretion) in Type 1 RTA significantly increases the risk of calcium phosphate stone formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type 1 (distal) RTA is characterized by hypokalemia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, inappropriately high urine pH (>5.5), hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria, which contribute to the development of nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis. Hyperkalemia is instead a feature of Type 4 RTA.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

A severe headache with neck rigidity and a positive CT finding strongly suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), the sign known as “Star of Death”. SAH is typically caused by the rupture of an aneurysm and presents with a sudden, severe headache often described as "the worst headache of my life." Neck rigidity is due to meningeal irritation caused by blood in the subarachnoid space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hemorrhage: Often presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms and is typically associated with trauma.

 

Option B. Pituitary apoplexy: Characterized by sudden headache, visual disturbances, and hormonal imbalances, not typically neck rigidity.

 

Option D. Pituitary carcinoma: Rare and presents with symptoms of mass effect and hormonal imbalance, not typically a severe headache with neck rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with a sudden severe headache and neck rigidity, often confirmed by CT.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothermia

 

The ECG shows long QT interval and J waves (Osborn waves), which are characteristic of hypothermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Shows tall T waves, widened QRS complexes, and absent P waves.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: Shows prominent U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Shows prolonged QT interval but no J waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is diagnosed with an ECG showing J waves and prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Streptococcus

 

Streptococcus, particularly Streptococcus viridans, is the most likely cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring late (more than 12 months after surgery). In the context of PVE, late cases are often similar to native valve endocarditis where Streptococcus viridans is a common pathogen due to its ability to adhere to damaged heart valves and form biofilms. The presentation of endocarditis 2 years post-surgery aligns with this etiological pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: While a common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (within the first 2 months), its prevalence decreases as the time post-surgery increases.

 

Option C. Coagulase negative staphylococci (CONS): These are more typical in early PVE cases, often within the first 2 months post-surgery, associated with intraoperative contamination.

 

Option D. HACEK organisms: These are a less common cause of endocarditis and are generally not the leading pathogens in prosthetic valve infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

 

  • Early (< 2 months): CONS > S. Aureus
  • Late (> 2-12 months): Similar to native valve -S. viridans

questions.text: What is the expected MCV in CBC based on the PS image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) > 100 fL

 

Explanation:

 

The peripheral smear (PS) image shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, which are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. In megaloblastic anemia, the red blood cells are larger than normal, leading to an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV).

 

Hypersegmented neutrophils are defined as neutrophils with 5 or more lobes, or at least one neutrophil with 6 or more lobes. Macro-ovalocytes are larger-than-normal red blood cells with an oval shape, which are indicative of a megaloblastic process.

 

The expected MCV in such cases is typically more than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. < 80 fL: This would indicate microcytic anemia.

 

Option B. < 60 fL: This would indicate severe microcytic anemia.

 

Option C. 80-100 fL: This is the normal range for MCV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes, the MCV is typically greater than 100 fL, indicating macrocytic anemia.

questions.text: Patient has problems in doing heel to shin test and repeatedly misses, and he has tremors in his hands. What is the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

 

Explanation

 

The heel-to-shin test is a classic test for cerebellar function, and difficulty or inaccuracy in performing this test indicates cerebellar dysfunction.

 

Additionally, the presence of tremors, particularly intention tremors, is characteristic of cerebellar lesions.

 

Cerebellar dysfunction can also present with other signs such as dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty with rapid alternating movements), dysmetria (inability to judge distance or scale), nystagmus, and ataxia (uncoordinated movement).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caudate: Lesions in the caudate nucleus are associated with chorea, characterized by involuntary, irregular, and unpredictable movements.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus: Lesions here typically result in dystonia and rigidity, not tremors or difficulty with the heel-to-shin test.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract: Lesions in the pyramidal tract lead to spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, not the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar lesions are indicated by difficulties with coordination tests such as the heel-to-shin test, presence of intention tremors, and other signs of ataxia. Recognizing these features helps in localizing the lesion to the cerebellum.

questions.text: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is caused by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occult filariasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE) is classified under "Pulmonary Infiltrates With Eosinophilia." It represents a hypersensitivity response to filarial parasites, specifically Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. The condition is characterized by peripheral eosinophilia, elevated IgE levels, and pulmonary infiltrates, typically occurring in endemic regions for filariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebral malaria: This is a severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum infection affecting the central nervous system. It has no relationship with pulmonary eosinophilia or the pathophysiology of TPE.

 

Option C. Pneumonic plague: This is caused by Yersinia pestis and presents as an acute infectious pneumonia with high fever, productive cough, and hemoptysis, without the characteristic eosinophilia seen in TPE.

 

Option D. Asthmatic bronchitis: While asthma can be associated with eosinophilia (such as in EGPA/Churg-Strauss syndrome), it is not the cause of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia, which is specifically related to filarial infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia is a manifestation of occult filariasis, characterized by pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia, and is distinct from other eosinophilic lung diseases like ABPA, Löffler's syndrome, and EGPA.

choices.text: Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type
Connective tissue disease of the mixed type

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most strongly associated with the presence of anti-centromere antibodies? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Syndrome characterized by CREST features.

 

Explanation: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), which is classically associated with the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). These antibodies show a strong association with clinical features including digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, and isolated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), while renal crisis is rarely seen in patients with this antibody pattern. Anti-centromere antibodies display a discrete speckled (centromere) pattern on immunofluorescence testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type: Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, not anti-centromere antibodies. These antibody patterns are mutually exclusive in systemic sclerosis.

 

Option B. Connective tissue disease of the mixed type: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterized by the presence of U1-RNP antibodies. Anti-centromere antibodies are not a serological feature of MCTD.

 

Option D. Inflammatory myopathy, particularly polymyositis: PM/Scl and anti-Jo antibodies are the serological markers associated with myositis overlap syndromes. Anti-centromere antibodies are not typically found in inflammatory myopathies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies have high specificity for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and the CREST variant, serving as important serological markers that help distinguish this clinical phenotype from other forms of systemic sclerosis and connective tissue disorders.

questions.text: What is the key mechanism leading to tissue damage in patients with prolonged diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

The primary mechanism leading to tissue damage in diabetes is persistent hyperglycemia, which:

 

  • Leads to oxidative stress
  • Promotes formation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs)
  • Causes endothelial dysfunction and inflammation

 

Most microvascular complications (neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy) are directly attributed to chronic hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol accumulation: Plays a secondary role, particularly in diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, but is not the primary cause of damage

 

Option C. Insulin resistance: Contributes to hyperglycemia, but does not directly cause tissue damage

 

Option D. Decreased insulin secretion: Leads to hyperglycemia, but tissue damage occurs due to persistent high glucose levels

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperglycemia is the fundamental mechanism causing tissue damage in prolonged diabetes, leading to various microvascular complications.

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.

 

Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

questions.text: A patient with long-standing multinodular goiter develops symptoms of thyrotoxicosis following exposure to iodine. What is this phenomenon called? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jod-Basedow phenomenon

 

The Jod-Basedow phenomenon occurs when a patient with pre-existing thyroid disease (such as multinodular goiter) develops thyrotoxicosis following iodine exposure. 

 

In diseased thyroid glands, instead of being suppressed by iodine as would happen in normal glands, the abnormal thyroid tissue takes up the excess iodine and produces more thyroid hormones, leading to or worsening thyrotoxicosis. This is why iodine-containing medications or contrast agents can precipitate thyroid storm in patients with pre-existing thyroid disease. This phenomenon is also the reason why in thyrotoxic patients, anti-thyroid drugs (like PTU) are given first to block hormone synthesis, and only after one hour is potassium iodide administered to suppress the gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolff-Chaikoff effect: This occurs in normal thyroid glands when they are exposed to excessive iodine, leading to temporary suppression of thyroid hormone synthesis. The gland typically escapes this effect after 8-9 days. This is the opposite of what occurs in the Jod-Basedow phenomenon.

 

Option C. Pemberton sign: This is a clinical sign of retrosternal goiter where raising both arms above the head for 1-2 minutes results in facial flushing, dyspnea, or stridor due to superior vena cava compression.

 

Option D. Plummer disease: This refers to toxic multinodular goiter, which is a chronic condition and not the acute phenomenon described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jod-Basedow phenomenon is the development of thyrotoxicosis in patients with pre-existing thyroid disease following iodine exposure, due to increased hormone production rather than suppression.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left atrium

 

In the case of mitral stenosis (MS), the obstruction at the mitral valve leads to increased pressure in the left atrium as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve. This increased pressure causes the left atrium to dilate. This dilation can be identified on a chest X-ray as enlargement of the left atrial silhouette. The left atrium enlargement is often the earliest and most prominent cardiac chamber change seen in mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Right atrium enlargement generally occurs later in the course of mitral stenosis as a consequence of the elevated pressure being transmitted back through the lungs to the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle is typically not directly affected by mitral stenosis, as this condition primarily impacts the left atrium. Left ventricular enlargement would be more characteristic of conditions affecting the left ventricular outflow or volume overload.

 

Option D. Right ventricle: Right ventricular enlargement may eventually occur if the disease progresses to the point of causing pulmonary hypertension, which then puts a strain on the right ventricle. However, this is a later development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest X-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

 

The patient's symptoms and the chest X-ray findings indicate pleural effusion. Key features of pleural effusion on a chest X-ray include the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. Clinically, pleural effusion leads to reduced or absent air entry in the affected area.

 

A dull note on percussion is a hallmark sign of pleural effusion. This occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which does not transmit sound vibrations as efficiently as air-filled lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperresonance on percussion: This finding is characteristic of pneumothorax, where there is an excess of air in the pleural space, leading to increased resonance.

 

Option B. Coarse crackles: Coarse crackles can be heard in various conditions such as bronchiectasis, the resolving phase of pneumonia, or pulmonary edema. However, they are not typically associated with pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Pleural rub: Pleural rub is a sign of pleuritis or inflammation of the pleura. It is usually absent in pleural effusion due to the separation of pleural surfaces by fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dull note on percussion is a key clinical finding in pleural effusion, indicating the presence of fluid in the pleural space.

questions.text:
LMN lesions are associated with? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Decrease in muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski positivity
  4. Fasciculations
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions are characterized by two features:

 

1. Decreased in muscle tone (flaccidity) – Due to interruption of the normal reflex arc

 

4. Fasciculations – Spontaneous twitching of muscle fibers due to denervation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis is a characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions

 

3. Babinski positivity sign (upgoing plantar response) is also a feature of UMN lesions

 

These features occur due to loss of inhibitory signals from upper motor neurons, which is not the case in LMN lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  1. Decreased muscle tone (flaccidity)
  2. Fasciculations (muscle twitching)
  3. Absence of spasticity and Babinski sign (which are UMN signs)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatinine

 

Explanation:

 

Child-Pugh scoring system is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. It involves five clinical measures of liver disease, including:

 

  1. Albumin
  2. Bilirubin
  3. Prothrombin Time (INR)
  4. Ascites
  5. Hepatic Encephalopathy

 

Creatinine is not included in the Child-Pugh scoring system. Instead, it is a component of the MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) score. The MELD score includes three parameters: creatinine, bilirubin, and INR. If it's MELD sodium, then it includes creatinine, bilirubin, INR, and sodium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin is a component of the Child-Pugh score. It helps assess the synthetic function of the liver.

 

Option B. Bilirubin: Bilirubin is another component of the Child-Pugh score. It indicates the liver's ability to excrete bile.

 

Option C. Prothrombin Time (INR): Prothrombin Time, measured as INR, is included in the Child-Pugh score to evaluate the liver's ability to produce clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Child-Pugh scoring system does not include creatinine as a parameter. Instead, creatinine is a part of the MELD score.

 

Note - The MELD score uses three parameters: Creatinine; Bilirubin and INR (International Normalized Ratio), so k/a CBI score. MELD Sodium Score includes Creatinine; Bilirubin; INR and sodium
